articles.headline: Buried in Details, a Warning to Investors
articles.snippet: A complex security marketed by Wells Fargo promised up to 30 years of monthly interest, but its early redemption, brought about by the Dodd-Frank law, meant big losses for investors.
articles.abstract: A complex security marketed by Wells Fargo promised up to 30 years of monthly interest, but its early redemption, brought about by the Dodd-Frank law, meant big losses for investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The bank that put together the unusual security did well. The customers who bought it suffered large losses. No one — at least no one who traded the security — seems to have understood the risks that were hidden deep in the prospectus.

articles.headline: Pile of Bills Is Left Behind as Congress Goes to Campaign
articles.snippet: A last-minute House attempt at relief for drought-stricken farmers was one of a series of measures that fell victim to partisan fighting, and infighting, in recent weeks.
articles.abstract: A last-minute House attempt at relief for drought-stricken farmers was one of a series of measures that fell victim to partisan fighting, and infighting, in recent weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An effort to provide emergency aid for American ranchers and farmers reeling from a year of drought, frost and other calamities collapsed on Thursday as members of Congress departed for their five-week August recess, leaving behind a pile of unfinished legislation as they go home to campaign for re-election.

articles.headline: Syrian Leader’s Arms Under Strain as Conflict Continues
articles.snippet: Many of the Syrian government’s most powerful weapons are looking less potent and in some cases like a liability for the military of President Bashar al-Assad.
articles.abstract: Many of the Syrian government’s most powerful weapons are looking less potent and in some cases like a liability for the military of President Bashar al-Assad.
articles.lead_paragraph: With diplomatic efforts dead and the future of Syria playing out on the battlefield, many of the Syrian government’s most powerful weapons, including helicopter gunships, fighter jets and tanks, are looking less potent and in some cases like a liability for the military of President Bashar al-Assad.

articles.headline: Errant Trades Reveal a Risk Few Expected
articles.snippet: By rushing to get a software trading program online, Knight Capital lost millions of dollars and created havoc on stock exchanges this week.
articles.abstract: By rushing to get a software trading program online, Knight Capital lost millions of dollars and created havoc on stock exchanges this week.
articles.lead_paragraph: The trading firm Knight Capital recently rushed to develop a computer program so it could take advantage of a new Wall Street venue for trading stocks.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Trying to Be Nimble, Knight Capital Stumbles
articles.snippet: Thomas M. Joyce, chief executive of the Knight Capital Group, has been an unapologetic advocate of electronic trading. After Wednesday’s trading debacle at Knight, he is fighting for the firm’s survival.
articles.abstract: Thomas M. Joyce, chief executive of the Knight Capital Group, has been an unapologetic advocate of electronic trading. After Wednesday’s trading debacle at Knight, he is fighting for the firm’s survival.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the leader of one of the largest brokerage firms in the nation, Thomas M. Joyce has been an unapologetic advocate of electronic trading and one of the most vociferous critics of companies that struggled to keep up with the ever-changing stock market.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Strong and Fast Markets, but No Time to Think
articles.snippet: Market makers who once might have stepped in during trading mishaps have largely been replaced by computers programmed to make lucrative high-frequency trades.
articles.abstract: Market makers who once might have stepped in during trading mishaps have largely been replaced by computers programmed to make lucrative high-frequency trades.
articles.lead_paragraph: Financial markets have greatly improved over the past quarter-century. Trading costs, whether for small individual investors or large institutional investors, have declined sharply. The cuts going to middlemen are smaller, and many markets are deeper and more liquid than ever.

articles.headline: Amid a Political Calm, a Tax Break for the Wind Industry Advances
articles.snippet: A Senate committee passed a bill in favor of a tax break for the wind industry on a bipartisan vote on Thursday, helped by Republicans from states where wind power is common.
articles.abstract: A Senate committee passed a bill in favor of a tax break for the wind industry on a bipartisan vote on Thursday, helped by Republicans from states where wind power is common.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been a tough year for companies in alternative energy.

articles.headline: After Recalls and Woes, Toyota Posts Huge Profit
articles.snippet: Toyota has surged back from a downturn following the natural disasters in Japan last year and is expecting to sell 23 percent more vehicles than it did in 2011.
articles.abstract: Toyota has surged back from a downturn following the natural disasters in Japan last year and is expecting to sell 23 percent more vehicles than it did in 2011.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Toyota roared back to a hefty profit in the first quarter and said on Friday that it intended to build a record-breaking 9.76 million cars this year, leading a recovery by Japanese automakers after a year of natural disasters and a punishingly strong currency.

articles.headline: Hiring Picks Up in July, but Data Gives No Clear Signal
articles.snippet: America added more jobs than expected, a pleasant surprise after months of bad news. But the underlying details from July ranged from unimpressive to outright discouraging.
articles.abstract: America added more jobs than expected, a pleasant surprise after months of bad news. But the underlying details from July ranged from unimpressive to outright discouraging.
articles.lead_paragraph: America added more jobs than expected last month, offering a pleasant surprise after many months of disappointing economic news. Even so, hiring was not strong enough to shrink the army of the unemployed in the slightest.
